scrape.title: The dinner
scrape.author: Neil
scrape.text: I don't have a problem with unreliable narrators or villains giving first-person perspectives, and I could be ok with both... if you made it plausible. This book did not. The first third I actually liked a lot, as a Bonfire-of-the-Vanities-style lampooning the very superficial/fake politician brother. The middle third got weird, but I was curious how it would work out. The final third was a total 180 in how multiple primary characters behaved, and simply didn't fit, especially the wife also being vile. Not inclined to read any more by this author.
